In October, sales dropped by almost 22%.
Their profit slumped around 20% in this second quarter.
Do consumers care?

You can still buy into CMG despite the downturn.
They need to continue implementing the protocols laid out in their recovery plan.
CMG could take up around $30 ‚Äì we had seen lows of orto high level.
Investors that believe the company can recover will continue to invest.
It takes courage but longterm investors understand that when good companies hit a bad spot its a buying opportunity.
Long-term it‚Äôs likely a winning pick due to chipotle re-committing on the quality of their products.
Fundamentally speaking, the long-term opportunity remains intact ‚Äì it is an amazing company, strong brand name etc.
I believe customer satisfaction will rebound once new protocols are established.
Some analysts see value here due to CMG trading near  8 times forward earnings (a discount).
That cheap valuation comes alongside improving fundamentals at the company.
Chipotle also has cash rich on its balance sheet, giving room for potential dividends & M&A.

Investors who buy or short sell the current price (below $420) should keep a careful eye on same store sales in Q2 ‚Äô16 results, as this critical metric influences investor optimism around CMG's turnaround prospects.
With an increased focus towards digital sales, customer personalization, and improving profit margins by cutting unnecessary business expenses (cost savings could benefit bottom line).
I do take some pride in being one of those early investors and riding this brand all the way through various cycles.
Still, Chipotle's crisis is deep-rooted, with sales plummeting and an overhang of ongoing legal probes/fines potentially weighing.
Not trying to make any judgments; but just wanted to say it seems some users are quite passionate about their love of Chipotle (and disappointment from current woes)?

Not convinced by the bull argument here either though, sorry üôÇ CMG faces major reputation hits + supply-chain management risks in their efforts to maintain food quality and avoid future outbreaks & contamination situations.
That‚Äôs crucial since word-of-mouth plays a lot into restaurants.

If you‚Äôre considering buying now though:
1‚É£ Monitor developments re recent recall news, company responses & sales outlook closely before entering / re-enterment CMG holdings.

Investors won't want be waiting years for recovery (as sales growth is still low) and patience is already wearing thin for what once saw explosive growth‚Ä¶ If they cannot fix and sustain these issues, market share may slip away.
Plus increased labor & operating costs.
Chipotle has changed menu labeling to increase customer information on preparation of some products etc.
Plus there remain lingering doubts around whether consumers have forgiven & forgotten the past safety issue woes?
Even more concerning is increased pressure from activist investors like Bill Ackman pushing for major change including a spinoff/push for profitability measures that could further disrupt operations.
Don‚Äôt count of customer loyalty: recent history has proven that.
That‚Äôll take some time + capital + resources.
Not yet sure about all they‚Äôre doing being effective long term while competitors might gain an edge because of past issues at CMG.
Also, competitors gained ground recently, as the burrito lovers have flocked to alternative options.
There are safer, stronger QSR industry options like Darden (DH).
Also a new CEO is in place, not as well-credentialed & less experienced compared to others.
Reassuring investors now depends significantly on convincing performance going forth; it may be some time before CMG proves stable recovery prospects.

Until proven otherwise, investors are simply unsure about buying into risk related volatility ü§ë If new management proves success after several quarters demonstrating commitment-to-solve- problems, yes maybe it becomes an enticing option üî•, especially if stock price doesn't budge for a few more periods üëÄ but for Now, CMG's path is quite uncertain.
Not an easy road ahead indeed.
Food-safety standards have become increasingly crucial given consumer pressure and regulatory scrutiny.
Time for Chipotle to regain customer trust.
Plus, don't forget their growth rate: it is already impacted by those past crises.
I also agree with @Darius‚Äôs concern that new competition from other established brands like Panera, YUM, Pizza Hut may erode further share for Chips.

Thanks so much for sharing your two cents üëçüëã üòÇ

Yeah don't be that quick üòâ to dismiss.
Also growth projections lowered significantly given current industry headwinds (slow traffic and sales) üéØ.
That being said, the best recovery is still possible as long as strong commitments and strategic moves towards that from within and especially outside perspectives would make all needed sense.
